greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of distinct prime factors of A181800(n) (n-th powerful number that is the first integer of its prime signature).
comment: Since each prime factor of A181800(n) divides A181800(n) at least twice, this is also the number of exponents > 2 in prime factorization of A181800(n).
Length of row A181800(n) of table A212171 equals a(n) for n > 1. Row A181800(n) of table A212172 has the same length when n > 1 (length = 1 if n = 1).
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: 72 (2^3*3^2) has 2 distinct prime factors. Since 72 = A181800(8), a(8) = 2.
results.author: _Matthew Vandermast_, Jun 04 2012
